This report was prepared by M. Sultana.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Poverty reduction is the overarching goal of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). The 
country  strategy  of  Pakistan  emphasizes  targeting  the  poor  for  social  services.  The  Local 
Government Ordinance (2001) of Pakistan has assigned the bulk of social services delivery to 
local governments at district, subdistricts, and union levels. However, weak service delivery 
mechanisms  at  the  local  level  remain  one  of  the  key  obstacles  in  addressing  poverty  in 
Pakistan. Emerging evidence shows that technical training of local service delivery agents is 
necessary, but not sufficient for improving the quality, efficiency, and affordability of social 
services. To be effective, joint planning, implementation, and monitoring of service delivery 
among the poor and marginalized citizens, locally elected representatives, and local service 
delivery agents are crucial. This technical assistance (TA) will build on evidence and develop a 
mechanism to  mobilize those key grassroots stakeholders to participate in pro-poor social 
service delivery under the Sindh Devolved Social Services Program (SDSSP).1  
 
2.  A concept paper was prepared to develop a model for targeting the poor, vulnerable, 
and  marginalized  groups  for  access  to  grassroots  social  services  under  SDSSP.  The  TA 
concept was endorsed for funding by the Poverty Reduction Cooperation Fund at its Fourth 
Strategy Meeting in January 2004.2 To further discuss the scope of this TA, a Fact-Finding 
Mission was undertaken in July 2004. To formulate appropriate activities and implementation 
arrangements for the TA, the Mission held detailed discussions with the Economic Affairs 
Division of the Ministry of Economic Affairs, concerned provincial government departments, 
locally elected representatives, civil society, nongovernment organizations (NGOs), and people 
from  various segments of local communities including women, the poor, and marginalized 
groups.  
 
                                                        II.   ISSUES 
3.  In Sindh, poverty increased from 27% in 1999 to 37% in 2001. Two thirds of the poor live 
in rural areas. Sindh faces a range of development issues including lack of basic services, a 
high incidence of health problems, low literacy rates, high population growth, weak rule of law, 
lack of access to justice, inaccessibility of capital, increased unemployment, and weak service 
delivery.  Social sector indicators are very poor. Half of the children below 5 years of age are 
malnourished, and 11% of them die before the age of 5. Of the survivors, half do not attend 
school. Gross enrollment rates stand at 38% for girls and 61% for boys. The total fertility rate is 
5 children per woman. Only 22% of the rural population have access to water supply schemes 
and rural sanitation coverage is only 9%. Of the 1,399 water and sanitation schemes in the 
province, 353 are nonfunctional. The total number of health facilities is 1,358 of which 650 are 
non-functional.3  The literacy rate for rural Sindh is 27% and school enrollment is 59%. These 
poor social indicators are linked to complex political and social structures, gender discrimination, 
poverty, weak governance, and lack of mechanisms for targeting the poor.  
 
4.  The rural society of Sindh is heterogeneous and polarized in terms of ethnicity, tribes, 
and caste, and these factors, together with gender, affect differently the level of poverty and 
vulnerability of men and women. In rural Sindh, social relationships are based on caste, tribe, 
and language and are further complicated by the skewed land tenure pattern. Landownership, 
relationships among tribes and castes, and gender determine much of the political and social

organization, the functioning of society, and access to resources. Social groups in the rural 
areas include landowners, sharecroppers (composed of both Muslim and Hindu scheduled 
castes), small and middle farmers, wage laborers, fisherfolk, artisans, and service households. 
Among these groups, sharecroppers, wage laborers, artisans, and fisherfolk are considered 
poor, vulnerable, and marginalized. Often development assistance does not reach these groups 
because of the lack of specific targeting mechanisms and inadequate strategies for mobilizing 
them. During the past decade, the Sindh government implemented a Social Action Program 
(SAP) to improve the delivery of social sector services. The experience of the SAP indicates the 
importance of broadening the social platform for the participation of stakeholders in designing 
and implementing development activities at the local level. Particularly important is having a 
specific social mobilization strategy for the poor, involvement of the beneficiaries, capacity 
building for the stakeholders, and good governance at the local level.    
 
5.  In  recent  years,  multilateral  agencies  have  undertaken  several  initiatives  to  address 
macro governance issues including administrative and system reforms in Pakistan. The World 
Bank has been supporting the provincial effort to improve financing and administration and 
pursue  civil  service  reforms.  ADB’s  Devolution  Support  Program  (DSP)  supports  macro 
governance, gender, and financial management reforms. The Sindh Poverty Reduction Strategy 
Paper (PRSP) emphasizes a three-pronged poverty reduction strategy, which includes the 
equitable delivery of social services to the poor. In the social sector, the PRSP aims to improve 
performance through better governance, stronger partnership with civil society, and needs-
based  allocation  of  resources.  The  Sindh  Local  Government  Ordinance  emphasizes 
strengthening the role of the community to Increase accountability and transparency.  
 
6.  In  Sindh,  government  ministries,  funding  agencies,  and NGOs  combined  have  been 
involved  in  programs  to  build  the  capacity  of  locally  elected  representatives.  In  general, 
however, the activities have not been focused on developing a systematic approach to building 
an institutional interface among the three key stakeholder groups for planning pro-poor services. 
These  essential  stakeholders  are  local-level  social  service  agencies;  locally  elected 
representatives; and the poor, vulnerable, and marginalized groups. The experience of ADB’s 
TA on gender and governance issues in local government in Bangladesh, Nepal, and Pakistan4 
suggests that grassroots forums and focused training to build the capacity of local stakeholders 
such as female and male locally elected representatives, officials from the sectoral agencies, 
poor and marginalized groups, civil society groups, and NGOs are critical in planning for the 
effective delivery of services, and addressing poverty at the local level. The findings of that TA 
show that improving the capacity of the locally elected representatives, and creating local-level 
forums have facilitated a transparent process for implementing development programs and 
better targeting the poor at the local level. 
 
7.  The following issues were identified by the TA Fact-Finding Mission: (i) services are 
more accessible to the higher- and middle-income groups than to the lower-income groups and 
the poor; (ii) poor and marginalized groups lack access to basic social services due partly to the 
lack of facilities and partly to the unfavorable attitude of the service providers toward those 
groups; (iii) inadequate capacity of many officials of the service delivery agencies at the local 
level hinders the effective targeting and delivery of resources; (iv) lack of clarity about the roles 
and responsibilities of locally elected representatives impedes their effective functioning; (v) 
ineffective planning, implementing, and monitoring of social services at the grassroots level 
indicate that local resources are often not well-utilized; (vi) lack of community involvement in 
and ownership of planning for services has resulted in poor outcomes of various development

3
and poverty schemes; (vii) local communities including the poor and marginalized groups lack 
information about development plans, schemes, budget allocations, and availability of social 
services; and (viii) lack of grassroots-level forums for the poor to voice their needs and to secure 
services for themselves impedes effective poverty reduction. 
 
8.  The TA loan for governance capacity building which is attached to the SDSSP includes 
capacity building for community-based organizations (CBOs), school management committees 
(SMCs), and village development associations (VDAs). However, in the CBOs, SMCs, and 
VDAs in rural Sindh there is little participation and representation of the poor or marginal 
groups. The SDSSP does not address specific social mobilization, capacity-building activities, 
and targeting mechanisms specifically for the poor and marginalized groups.  The model for pro-
poor  service  delivery,  to  be  developed  by  this  TA,  will  help  subsequent  activities  to  be 
undertaken in the remaining 14 districts of Sindh under the TA loan for governance capacity 
building, attached to the SDSSP. It is assumed that the cost of replicating the model can be 
financed by this TA loan attached to the SDSSP. 
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.   Purpose and Output 
 
9.    The TA will develop a transparent grassroots-level decision-making model for pro-poor 
social service delivery under the SDSSP. The model will build on an institutionalized interface 
among elected people’s representatives, officials from the social service agencies, poor people, 
and marginalized groups. The outputs will be increased access to social services by the poor 
and marginalized groups; and a better understanding by social service providers and locally 
elected representatives of their own roles and responsibilities in planning and delivering of pro-
poor services. The TA framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
B.    Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.   The TA will consist of the following activities: (i) social mobilization of community-based 
groups of the poor and marginalized groups; (ii) training programs to build the capacity of men 
and  women  locally  elected  representatives  and  the  local  social  service  agencies;  (iii) 
establishment of local-level social development forums to promote the institutional interface 
among social service agencies, locally elected representatives, poor and marginalized groups, 
NGOs,  and  civil  society  groups;  (iv)  promotion  of  grassroots-level  monitoring  of  pro-poor 
services; (v) creation of provincial-level workshops to share experiences and lessons learned 
from the two pilot districts (Khairpur and Tharparkar) and to develop strategies to be applied on 
a  larger  scale  in  the  SDSSP;  and  (vi)  appointment  of  a  project  steering  committee  for 
monitoring, disseminating and scaling up the TA activities through the SDSSP. 
 
11.  The TA will strengthen the institutional capacity of community-based groups of the poor, 
vulnerable, and marginalized people at the grassroots level for systematic representation in 
CBOs/VDAs.  At  least  50%  of  the  groups  will  consist  of  females.  Social  mobilization  and 
institutional  capacity  building  for  community-based  groups  of  the  poor  will  increase  their 
knowledge about existing poverty programs and social service schemes such as those for 
education, health, water, and sanitation, and will increase their ability to negotiate services for 
themselves. Access of the poor to information about various social services at the community 
level will increase the demand for pro-poor social services and increase the accountability of 
local administrative bodies and social service agencies.

4  
 
12.  The  focused  capacity-building  training  of  locally  elected  representatives  and  social 
service providers will enhance their awareness and skills and thus facilitate pro-poor planning, 
implementation, and monitoring of social services at the grassroots level. Capacity building 
training  will  focus  on  the  following:  (i)  the  roles  and  responsibilities  of  the  respective 
stakeholders  and  their  institutions;  (ii)  dissemination  of  information  about  local-level  social 
sector programs and their implementation modalities; (iii) understanding the social exclusion of 
the  poor,  vulnerable,  and  marginalized  groups;  (iv)  learning  about  planning  and  targeting 
mechanisms for better services for the poor; (v) gender sensitization for gender-based planning 
and resource allocation; and (vi) grassroots-level participatory monitoring of social services. 
Training community-based groups of poor men and women will include awareness raising, 
leadership building, local resource mobilization, planning and negotiating skills, and so on.  
 
13.  Social development forums will be developed at three local government levels: union 
council, subdistrict, and district. Each social development forum will include representatives of 
the  various  stakeholders  such  as  male  and  female  locally  elected  representatives,  local 
government officials, officials from social service agencies, community-based groups of the poor 
and  marginalized,  NGOs,  civil  society  groups,  citizen’s  resource  centers,  and  the 
Insaf/Musalihat (justice and reconciliation) committees. The union council forum will provide the 
primary interface among the poor people, elected representatives of the local bodies, and 
government  agencies  implementing  social  sector  programs  at  the  community  level.  The 
interface created among various stakeholders in this forum will encourage transparent and 
participatory monitoring processes for social service delivery at the grassroots level. Monitoring 
indicators will be developed and used by local people to track the effects of pro-poor social 
services. Forums at the subdistricts and districts will generally be responsible for addressing the 
needs  and  issues  identified  at  the  union  council  and  for  supervising  and  monitoring  the 
implementation of social sector programs for the poor.   
 
14.  The TA will be implemented on a pilot basis in Khairpur and Tharparkar districts. The 
districts were selected through discussions with the concerned government agencies and the 
district government. Selection criteria included concentration of poor and marginalized groups, 
topography, and leadership capacity of the district government. The pilot union councils in each 
district will be identified in collaboration with the district government. Baseline surveys will be 
conducted in the pilot union councils to determine the availability of existing social services to 
the poor, vulnerable, and marginalized groups. The survey data will be compared with results 
from pilot union councils and non-pilot union councils at the end of the TA.   
        
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $625,000 equivalent comprising $71,000 in 
foreign exchange and $554,000 equivalent in local currency.  ADB will finance the entire foreign 
exchange cost of $71,000 and $429,000 equivalent of the local currency cost. The TA will be 
financed by the Poverty Reduction Cooperation Fund on a grant basis. The fund will be used for 
financing international and domestic consultants, NGO contracts including preparing training 
materials, delivering the training, and implementing field activities. The government of Sindh will 
provide $125,000 equivalent primarily through in-kind contributions to cover accommodation, 
venue  for  training,  workshop,  transport,  counterpart  staff  support,  and  monitoring  the  field 
activities.  The TA will be administered by ADB. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan  
are in Appendix 2.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The Executing Agency of the TA will be the Finance Department (FD) of the government 
of Sindh. The FD will have an advisory and supervisory role.  It will monitor activities through the 
Project Support Unit (PSU) and Local Support Unit (LSU) of the SDSSP. The project steering 
committee (PSC) will be established in FD with the secretary of finance as chairperson. The 
members of the committee will include the chief economist for planning and development; 
Secretaries (or their representatives not below Special Secretary or Additional Secretary) of the 
departments of local government, education, health and women development; project directors 
of the SDSSP and DSP; district nazims and district coordination officers (DCOs) of the TA 
project districts; and selected representatives from the union council social development forum 
and TA project NGOs. The project director of the SDSSP will facilitate secretarial work of the 
PSC. 
  
17.  The  TA  activities  will  be  implemented  by  national  NGOs,  recruited  according  to 
procedures acceptable to ADB. The NGOs will be eligible for selection based on their previous 
experience  in  implementing  poverty  reduction  and  service  delivery  projects,  in  developing 
training  modules  and  conducting  participatory  training  for  grassroots-level  stakeholders,  in 
training local government representatives, and in facilitating social mobilization activities for the 
poor and marginalized groups. Experience in implementing ADB projects will be an advantage. 
The TA will require 7 person-months of consulting services: 4 domestic and 3 international. The 
consultants will be recruited individually in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants. The terms of reference of the consultants and participating NGOs are in Appendix 
3.   
18.  The TA will be implemented over 2 years and is expected to start in January 2005 and 
be completed in December 2007. The first month will be used to select the NGOs. The next 2 
months will focus on reconnaissance visits to the field to select the union councils and identify 
community-based groups of the poor, vulnerable, and marginalized. Also to be completed in this 
period are an assessment of the training needs of various stakeholders and development of 
training  modules.  Capacity-building  training  for  stakeholders,  the  initial  formation  of  social 
development forums, and various social mobilization activities will start from month 4. The 
training of the elected representatives and the local-level service providers will be completed by 
the end of the month 8. Activities of the social development forums and social mobilization will 
continue throughout the project period. Participating NGOs will submit an inception report within 
the first 2 months of implementation. A provincial workshop will be held after the first 12 months, 
and another at the end of the TA.  The international consultant will prepare the final report 
detailing  the  results  of  the  TA  and  will  submit  to  ADB  1  month  before  the  end  of  the 
implementation period.   
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
19.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to the Government 
of Pakistan to be financed on a grant basis by the Poverty Reduction Cooperation Fund for   
Mobilization  of  Grassroots  Stakeholders  for  Pro-Poor  Social  Service  Delivery  (Sindh),  and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTING SERVICES AND NONGOVERNMENT 
ORGANIZATIONS  
 
 
A.  Nongovernment Organizations (NGOs) 
1.  Four national NGOs will be responsible for implementing the technical assistance (TA). 
The  NGOs  will  be  eligible  for  selection  on  the  basis  of  their  previous  work  with  rural 
communities especially the poor and marginalized groups, to implement projects focused on 
poverty reduction, service delivery, and social mobilization activities. The NGOs should have 
significant experience in working with local-level governments, developing training modules, and 
conducting participatory training for grassroots stakeholders. The NGOs will be responsible for 
the following tasks in the two project districts (Kharipur and Tharparkar):  
(i)  Select  pilot  union  councils  with  a  concentration  of  poor,  vulnerable,  and 
marginalized groups from the two project districts in collaboration with the district 
government; Identify informal and formal community-based groups of the poor 
and marginalized  (men and women groups) in the pilot union councils. Conduct 
a baseline survey of the social and economic status of those groups, constraints 
related to access to social service and social safety net programs; their present 
involvement  in  specific  development  activities/committees,  such  as  village 
development association (VDA), school management committee (SMC); access 
to  social  services,  i.e.,  water,  sanitation,  health  services,  nutrition  programs,

B.  International Consultant (3 person-months) 
2.  One international consultant will be recruited on an individual basis for 3 person-months. 
The consultant should have substantial working experience in South Asia on poverty reduction 
projects, local level governance issues, and NGOs.  
 
3.  The responsibilities of the international consultant will be as follows: 
 
(i)  Review  and  assess  the  project  activities  in  the  various  components  and 
implementation strategies. Conduct field research based on the tools developed 
by ADB (Social Sectors Division and Economic Research Division) and collect 
information  from  pilot  and  nonpilot  union  councils,  interview  relevant 
stakeholders, including poor and marginalized group members, and compare 
data from the pilot testing with the base survey for the final reports. 
 
(ii)  Based  on  experience  from  the  pilot  initiatives,  and  other  agency  initiatives, 
prepare the final report highlighting key factors related to effective social service 
delivery to the poor and marginalized men and women groups.   
 
(iii)  Recommend strategies for incorporating the pilot experience on a larger scale in 
SDSSP. 
 
(iv)  Prepare policy recommendations for formulating effective mechanisms for pro-
poor service delivery at the local level.
